fact_list.fact_text: Class 4 licences are for heavy motor cars of an unladen weight exceeding 2500 kg and constructed to carry a load or passengers, as well as motor tractors of an unladen weight between 2500 kg and 7250 kg.
Class 5 licences are for motor vehicles of an unladen weight exceeding 7250 kg and not constructed to carry any load.
Applicants must be at least 21 years old and in possession of a Class 3 Qualified Licence.
Applicants must be at least 21 years old and in possession of a Class 4 Qualified Licence.
An applicant for a new class of licence must pass the test of competence to drive, which includes the theory and/or practical driving/riding tests.
The Basic Theory Test (BTT) is designed to test knowledge of traffic rules, traffic regulations, traffic signs and signals, as well as general road safety.
All learner drivers and riders must obtain a pass for BTT before they can proceed to take the advanced theory test.
After passing the BTT, individuals who want to obtain a motorcar driving licence (Class 3 or 3A) must pass the Final Theory Test (FTT) before taking the Practical Driving Test.
The Final Theory Test (FTT) tests knowledge on driving safety aspects, proper techniques of driving, and interaction with other road users.
After passing the FTT, individuals must pass the Practical Driving Test within two years, failing which they must retake and pass the FTT again before applying for another Practical Driving Test.
After passing the BTT, individuals who want a motorcycle driving licence (Class 2B) must pass the Riding Theory Test (RTT) before taking the Practical Riding Test.
The Riding Theory Test (RTT) tests knowledge on riding safety aspects, proper techniques of riding, and interaction with other road users.
After passing the RTT, individuals must pass the Practical Riding Test within one year, failing which they must retake and pass the RTT again before applying for another Practical Riding Test.
The Practical Driving/Riding Test will be conducted by a Driving Examiner appointed by the Traffic Police.

Applicants taking theory or practical driving/riding tests must not have accumulated more than 12 demerit points, must not be under suspension or Court disqualification, and must be free from certain other restrictions.
Probation Plate rules apply to new drivers during their probation as outlined in related offences.
After passing the Basic Theory Test (BTT), applicants may apply for a Provisional Driving Licence (PDL) to start learning to drive or ride on the roads with a driving instructor.
A PDL is valid for two years from the date of grant and can be renewed for additional two-year periods.
PDL holders must display 'L' plates on their vehicles during driving lessons and tests, and be insured against third-party risk.
PDL holders can only drive under the supervision of a licensed driving instructor or a driving schoolâ€™s driving instructor.

To apply for a PDL, applicants must not have accumulated more than 12 demerit points, must have passed the BTT, be able to read letters and figures at a distance of 25 meters, and distinguish red, amber, and green colors at the same distance.
Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents have driving licences valid for their lifetime.
Foreigners with work passes granted by the Ministry of Manpower have driving licences valid for up to 5 years.
